叶夫根尼·普里戈任的瓦格纳集团的一名高级指挥官表示，该集团的雇佣兵正准备根据一项协议的条款前往白俄罗斯，该协议平息了他们对俄罗斯军事领导层的叛变。

6月23日至24日的兵变中，瓦格纳武装分子短暂占领了俄罗斯南部城市并向莫斯科进军，自那次兵变以来，普里戈任和他的雇佣兵的确切下落一直不清楚。

根据结束叛乱的协议，普里戈任本应转移到白俄罗斯，而他的部下——其中一些人是提前获释去乌克兰作战的——可以选择与他一起转移到白俄罗斯，加入俄罗斯正规武装部队，或者回家。

然而，白俄罗斯总统亚历山大·卢卡申科周四表示，普里戈任和他的数千名战士仍在俄罗斯，引发了对该协议执行情况的质疑。

周六，Telegram 消息应用程序的一个频道援引化名“Lotus”的安东·叶利扎罗夫的话说，根据普里戈任的命令，战士们现在休假到八月初，然后再前往白俄罗斯。

“我们必须准备基地、训练场，与地方政府和行政部门协调，组织与白俄罗斯执法机构的互动并建立后勤保障，”“Yevgeny Prigozhin on Telegram”频道援引他的话说。

路透社无法核实采访的真实性。

过去两周，普里戈任本人一反常态地保持沉默。自 6 月 26 日为武装分子的叛乱行为 辩护以来，他就没有在他以前喜欢的 Telegram 频道——叶夫根尼·普里戈任新闻服务处发帖。

空营

白俄罗斯国防部顾问周五表示，瓦格纳集团尚未有人参观过卢卡申科提供给战士使用的废弃军营。

叶利扎罗夫表示，自兵变以来，俄罗斯安全部队没有试图“打击”瓦格纳战士。

普里戈任长期以来一直强烈批评俄罗斯国防部和总参谋长对乌克兰战争的处理方式，他表示，他向莫斯科发起了“正义游行”，以抗议高层官员的腐败和无能。

当被问及俄罗斯官方媒体最近对普里戈任的袭击时，叶利扎罗夫表示，这是俄罗斯军事机构试图离间这位雇佣兵首领和他的瓦格纳战士之间的关系。

他说，这一尝试将会失败，因为“当国家不需要我们时”，普里戈任自己创造并塑造了瓦格纳战士。叶利扎罗夫将普里戈任和他的部下比作神话中的亚瑟王和他的圆桌骑士。

本周，俄罗斯国家电视台播放了据称是执法人员突袭普里戈任圣彼得堡办公室及其一处“宫殿”时拍摄的镜头。

报告称，尽管 6 月 24 日达成协议，但针对普里戈任的调查仍在进行中，根据该协议，对他因叛乱失败而提出的刑事指控被撤销。

加雷斯·琼斯撰写；艾莉森·威廉姆斯编辑; Sat, 08 Jul 2023 11:44:00 GMT https://www.reuters.com/world/europe/wagner-fighters-preparing-move-belarus-commander-cited-2023-07-08/ https://www.reuters.com/world/europe/wagner-fighters-preparing-move-belarus-commander-cited-2023-07-08/Reuters乌克兰危机/瓦格纳白俄罗斯 San Francisco's new venture capital hotspot: The Presidio

风险投资公司 Headline 曾经位于旧金山最引人注目的摩天大楼之一：几十年来一直定义着天际线的金字塔形 Transamerica 大楼。员工们享受 43 楼的美景和市中心的便利。

然后大流行来了。

随着科技行业转向在家工作或缩小规模，本来就饱受毒品和无家可归困扰的市中心进一步陷入城市衰败。企业关门，游客被吓跑，形成恶性循环，同时该市房地产市场已经发生变化。

随着 Headline 的租约到期，该公司决定寻找其他地方。高管们考虑在船上建造办公室或搬到住宅。最终，他们将管理 40 亿美元的业务转移到了田园风光且安全的普雷西迪奥 (Presidio)，普雷西迪奥是一座前军事基地，现已改建为国家公园，毗邻地标性建筑金门大桥。

他们并不孤单。风险投资公司越来越多地与零售商和其他企业一起在旧金山市中心以外寻找住房。例如，Westfield 上个月表示，由于人流量较 2019 年下降了 43%，该公司将放弃经营 20 年的市中心购物中心。

风险投资公司的最终走向可能会对更广泛的科技行业产生影响，因为此类公司通常有助于形成初创公司创始人和社区的重心。

Headline 执行合伙人马蒂亚斯·席林 (Mathias Schilling) 在最近一个阳光明媚的下午说道：“Presidio 确实代表了我们对未来工作的看法。”附近明亮的厨房里，十几名员工坐在一张长木公用桌旁，在郁郁葱葱的绿色植物、棕榈树和旧金山湾的全景背景下吃午餐。

“这是一个非常平静的空间，我认为这可以灌输创造力并激励人们，”席林说。 “我们在外面开会，然后在这里的大草坪上散步。”

其他风险投资家——包括支持 Shopify 和 Fitbit 的 Felicis Ventures，以及 Forerunner Ventures 和风险投资工作室 Atomic，已经在莱特曼大厦（普雷西迪奥最大的办公大楼之一）中占据了名录。

Presidio 由前军事基地改建而成，位于旧金山半岛的顶端，金融区以西几英里处。作为国家公园，它由联邦警察巡逻。

“感觉比市中心100%安全。普雷西迪奥没有公开吸毒的地方。没有无家可归者的营地。很少有无家可归者四处游荡，那是因为这是联邦土地，联邦警察是其中的重要组成部分， ”雷克斯·索尔兹伯里 (Rex Salisbury) 说道，他经营风险投资公司 Cambrian Venture，自 2017 年以来一直在 Presidio 生活和工作。

技术生态系统的转变

风险投资公司在旧金山湾区的科技生态系统中发挥着不可或缺的作用，该地区的初创公司在 2022 年获得了美国所有风险投资资金的约 35%。

自 20 世纪 90 年代互联网繁荣以来，风投们纷纷聚集在距离初创公司创始人较近的热点地区，包括硅谷的沙山路和旧金山市中心的南方公园。

现在，一些公司表示，他们觉得没有必要留在市中心，因为自疫情以来，初创公司创始人变得更加分散，而对于居住在城市北部或金门对面的马林县的公司合作伙伴来说，Presidio 是一个便利的地点来自旧金山的大桥。

“在新冠疫情之前，Presidio 距离任何创始人来说都太远了。创始人不再在市中心了，所以我们不必再去那里了。我们觉得这不会成为我们的负担。” “创始人来到这里。他们实际上非常兴奋，”尤里·金 (Eurie Kim) 说道，她的风险投资公司 Forerunner 于 2022 年初离开市中心前往普雷西迪奥 (Presidio)。

尽管没有按社区划分的风险投资公司分布情况的统计数据，但根据房地产数据，Presidio 的空置率约为 5%，而旧金山商业地产整体空置率为 35%，高于疫情前的 4%。房地产公司 CBRE 和管理该地区的联邦机构 Presidio Trust。

尽管根据 CBRE 的数据，Presidio 的商业地产平均比市中心贵 20%，但情况还是如此。

Presidio Trust 发言人丽莎·皮特里 (Lisa Petrie) 表示，自 2020 年以来，人们对从市中心搬到这里的兴趣浓厚。“他们都将这个城市国家公园的便利设施和美丽的环境作为定居于此的首要原因，”她补充道。

Presidio 长期以来一直吸引着非营利组织和娱乐公司。卢卡斯影业 (Lucasfilm) 自 2005 年起将总部设于此，华特迪士尼家族博物馆 (Walt Disney Family Museum) 于 2009 年在公园内开业。

然而，一些风险投资家表示，他们仍然致力于市中心。今年早些时候，当 General Catalyst 位于旧金山南公园的办公室规模超出其规模时，他们搬到了几个街区外的另一座市中心大楼。

General Catalyst 首席技术官乔恩·雷哈根 (Jon Rehagen) 表示：“我们找到了一个靠近公共交通、市中心酒店和餐馆的便利地点。”他补充说，该公司正在与当地餐馆和服务提供商合作。 “希望这将有助于重振疫情后仍在恢复的市中心科技走廊。”

Presidio 的员工也希望市中心能够恢复，但表示目前他们很高兴不再需要在那里通勤。

Headline 品牌副总裁莫莉·马泰尔 (Molly Martell) 表示：“城镇的这一部分已经很久没有发展了。”她说，她希望对其问题的关注将成为变革的催化剂。 “看到正在发生的事情真是悲惨，”她补充道。

旧金山市长办公室发言人伦敦·布里德表示，政府希望支持该市所有社区的各类企业。

“布里德市长将继续实施战略举措，帮助稳定现有企业并招募新企业​​，作为旧金山市中心未来计划路线图的一部分。我们将继续强调支持市中心振兴的努力，但我们也欢迎各方面的投资我们的城市，”发言人在一封电子邮件中说。

世邦魏理仕 Tech Insight 执行董事 Colin Yasukochi 将 Presidio 与硅谷风投历史悠久的地址 Sand Hill Road 进行了比较。

他说：“我们这里的房地产确实存在这种现象，我们称之为‘追求质量’。” “普雷西迪奥 (Presidio) 已发展成为旧金山的沙山路 (Sand Hill Road)。”

胡晶晶报道；由 Peter Henderson 和 Rosalba O'Brien 编辑; Sat, 08 Jul 2023 10:23:23 GMT https://www.reuters.com/world/us/san-franciscos-new-venture-capital-hotspot-national-park-world-away-downtown-2023-07-08/ https://www.reuters.com/world/us/san-franciscos-new-venture-capital-hotspot-national-park-world-away-downtown-2023-07-08/Krystal Hu旧金山风险投资/（PIX、电视） Dutch Prime Minister Rutte to update king on government collapse

荷兰首相马克·吕特定于周六会见威廉·亚历山大国王，讨论看守政府的问题，第二天他的中右翼政府因移民政策问题而垮台。

联合政府辞职意味着议会很可能会被解散，荷兰将在预计于11月举行的大选中进行投票。

现年 56 岁的吕特自 2010 年开始执政，目前已是荷兰任期最长的首相。他在周五晚些时候的新闻发布会上表示，他希望竞选第五个任期，但在做出最终决定之前会与他的政党协商。

“如果你让我现在决定，答案显然是‘是’，”他告诉记者，但补充说“这也取决于党”。

荷兰政坛危机发生在吕特领导的保守党 VVD 推动限制寻求庇护者涌入荷兰之后。

本周，紧张局势达到了顶峰，吕特要求支持一项提案，该提案限制已在荷兰的战争难民儿童的入境，并要求家庭至少等待两年才能团聚。

这项最新提议遭到了小型基督教联盟和自由派 D66 的反对，导致僵局并最终导致政府垮台。

作为国家元首，威廉-亚历山大国王预计将要求吕特的联盟继续担任看守政府，直至新选举后组建新政府，而在分裂的荷兰政治格局中，这一过程通常需要数月时间。

自2015-2016年移民危机以来，移民问题还从未成为欧洲政治的断层线。

过去六个月，德国极右翼选择党的支持率大幅上升。西班牙民意调查显示，极右翼 Vox 党可能在本月晚些时候举行的提前选举后进入政府。

在荷兰，农民对政府限制氮排放计划的抗议在一定程度上给移民蒙上阴影，他们称这项政策将导致许多农场的终结。

农民抗议党 BBB 成为三月份省级选举中最大的政党，该选举决定了荷兰参议院的组成。

在政府垮台前一周进行的最新 Ipsos 民意调查中，吕特领导的 VVD 预计将在拥有 150 个席位的议会中占据 28 个席位，继续成为第一大党。但 BBB 预计将从目前的 1 个席位激增至 23 个，成为议会第二大党。

虽然 BBB 主要关注政府的氮排放计划，但它也支持更严格的移民政策，并建议每年可能限制 15,000 名寻求庇护者。

荷兰已经拥有欧洲最严厉的移民政策之一。去年，荷兰的庇护申请增加了三分之一，达到 46,000 多份，政府预计今年申请量可能会增加到 70,000 多份，超过 2015 年的最高纪录。

斯蒂芬妮·范登伯格报道；罗斯·拉塞尔编辑; Sat, 08 Jul 2023 09:52:07 GMT https://www.reuters.com/world/europe/dutch-prime-minister-rutte-update-king-government-collapse-2023-07-08/ https://www.reuters.com/world/europe/dutch-prime-minister-rutte-update-king-government-collapse-2023-07-08/Reuters荷兰政府/（PIX、电视） NATO flexes muscle to protect Vilnius summit near Russia, BelarusSummary:
  • 维尔纽斯成为峰会的戒备森严的堡垒
  • 盟国投入先进武器来保卫北约领导人
  • 地点距离白俄罗斯边境仅 32 公里（20 英里）
  • 盟国派遣军队、喷气式飞机、防空部队、炮兵、警察
  • 立陶宛领导人希望北约永久保卫波罗的海天空

北约已将维尔纽斯变成了一座由先进武器保卫的堡垒，以保护美国总统乔·拜登和其他联盟领导人下周举行的会议，距离立陶宛与俄罗斯盟友白俄罗斯的边界围栏仅 32 公里（20 英里）。

16个北约盟国总共派出了约1,000名士兵来保卫7月11日至12日举行的峰会，峰会将在距离俄罗斯本土仅151公里（94英里）的地方举行。许多国家还提供波罗的海国家所缺乏的先进防空系统。

立陶宛总统吉塔纳斯·瑙塞达表示：“在拜登和 40 个国家的领导人抵达之际，如果我们的天空不受保护，那将是非常不负责任的行为。”

立陶宛、爱沙尼亚和拉脱维亚等波罗的海国家曾受莫斯科统治，但自 2024 年起成为北约和欧盟的一部分，它们的国防支出均占其经济的 2% 以上，这一比例高于大多数其他北约盟国。

但对于总人口约600万的地区来说，这不足以维持庞大的军队、投资自己的战斗机或先进的防空系统。

德国部署了12辆爱国者导弹发射器，用于拦截弹道导弹、巡航导弹或战机。

西班牙带来了NASAMS防空系统，法国正在派遣凯撒自行榴弹炮，法国、芬兰和丹麦正在立陶宛部署军用飞机，英国和法国正在提供反无人机能力。

波兰和德国派出了直升机增强型特种作战部队。其他国家正在采取措施应对任何潜在的化学、生物、放射性和核攻击。

对于瑙塞达来说，盟军为确保领导人聚会期间的空中安全所做的努力意味着北约需要紧急在波罗的海国家建立永久性防空系统。

他对记者说：“我们考虑峰会结束后会发生什么，我们将与盟国合作，建立一支轮换部队，以提供永久的空中保护。”

没有胆量'

在白俄罗斯边境附近的村庄，当地人告诉路透社，尽管俄罗斯盟友提出容纳俄罗斯私人瓦格纳民兵并拥有俄罗斯核武器，但他们感到完全安全。

“你认为瓦格纳或白俄罗斯会攻击立陶宛吗？立陶宛是北约成员国？他们没有胆量。北约就是北约，我们因为在北约而感到安全。为什么我们会害怕那些白俄罗斯人？”爱德华说。 Rynkun，67 岁，位于距离白俄罗斯 1 公里（不到一英里）的卡纽凯村。

“如果立陶宛单独存在，我会有不同的感受，”他补充道。 “如果不是北约成员国，这里的情况可能已经和乌克兰一样了，”林昆的邻居、55 岁的埃琳娜·塔拉塞维奇 (Elena Tarasevic) 说。

在维尔纽斯机场，有人看到八个德国运营的爱国者导弹发射器，其喷嘴指向俄罗斯加里宁格勒方向。还有两个指向白俄罗斯。自周五早上以来，所有发射器均已投入运行。

爱国者部署指挥官斯特芬·利布中校说：“你知道自己的地理位置，也很清楚威胁来自哪里。”

“立陶宛请求我们保护峰会，北约也向德国请求帮助。这就是我们的答案，”他补充道。

三重LED

今年夏天，立陶宛在白俄罗斯和俄罗斯边境部署的边防警卫数量增加了两倍，并增派了来自拉脱维亚和波兰的官员。两国还派出警察协助维尔纽斯巡逻。

边防卫队长鲁斯塔马斯·柳巴耶瓦斯说：“我们正在为各种挑衅做准备”。他补充说，他担心边境出现一波又一波的移民潮，或者侵犯边境，或者军车在没有任何解释的情况下出现在边境。

2021 年，数千名中东移民越过白俄罗斯边境，立陶宛和欧盟称这是明斯克精心策划的，但立陶宛否认了这一指控。此后数字有所下降。

“由于俄罗斯对乌克兰的侵略，局势确实非常紧张。因此（边境保护）（在峰会之前）已经处于非常非常高的水平”，柳巴耶瓦斯说。

日本周六标志着前首相安倍晋三在一次选举演讲中被一名因他与统一教会的联系而愤怒的男子枪杀一周年。

日本任职时间最长的首相的去世被视频记录下来，这让这个不习惯枪支暴力的国家感到不安。

日本首相岸田文雄以及其他高级官员和议员与安倍的遗孀昭惠一起参加了在东京一座佛教寺庙举行的私人追悼会。仪式结束后，公众被允许进场献花。

其中包括 49 岁的酒店工作人员小川津，她在安倍遇刺当天庆祝了自己的生日。

"I was shocked that such a terrible thing as this could happen in Japan, and I pray that such a thing never happens again," she said carrying flowers to the temple.

Abe is remembered for pursuing economic policies aimed at ending years of deflation, including aggressive monetary easing, fiscal stimulus and deregulation. Critics said those measures also opened up an income gap.

Abe, who stepped down in 2020, also championed an aggressive defence policy that increased military spending and reinterpreted Japan's war-renouncing constitution to allow Japanese troops to fight overseas for the first time since World War Two.

"I will support politicians who carry on the work of Abe's administration," Atsuhiro Ueda, a 35-year-old office worker, said as he joined others at the temple.

While Kishida has stepped back from Abe's economic agenda, he has maintained his predecessor's hawkish policies, announcing last year that Japan would double defence spending .

BACKLASH

Abe's death triggered a public backlash against the ruling Liberal Democratic Party after close links between it and the Unification Church came to light.

Tetsuya Yamagami 42, who has yet to stand trial, is suspected of using a handmade firearm fashioned out of metal and wood to kill the 67-year-old politician. In social media posts before the shooting, he blamed the Unification Church for leaving his mother in financial straits.

Known globally for its mass weddings, the South Korean church has been blamed for causing financial hardship by seeking large donations from its followers.

Revelations that Abe and more than half of all LDP lawmakers had links to the church, with some accepting donations or using its followers as election workers, prompted high-level resignations, including that of Economic Revitalisation Minister Daishiro Yamagiwa.

Although Kishida was not among them, his public support slumped in the aftermath of the scandal.

In April, concern about political violence erupted again after a man threw what appeared to be a pipe bomb at Kishida during an appearance in western Japan. He escaped unhurt .

The United States announced on Friday that it would supply Ukraine with widely-banned cluster munitions for its counteroffensive against occupying Russian forces, and NATO's leader said the military alliance would unite at a summit next week on how to bring Ukraine closer to joining.

Rights groups and the United Nations secretary-general questioned Washington's decision on the munitions, part of an $800 million security package that brings total US military aid to more than $40 billion since Russia's February 2022 invasion of Ukraine.

Russian President Vladimir Putin, who describes the conflict as a "special military operation" to protect Russian security, has said the US and its allies were fighting an expanding proxy war.

The cluster munitions "will deliver in a time frame that is relevant for the counteroffensive," a Pentagon official told reporters.

Cluster munitions are prohibited by more than 100 countries. They typically release large numbers of smaller bomblets that can kill indiscriminately over a wide area and those that fail to explode pose a danger for decades after a conflict ends.

"Ukraine has provided written assurances that it is going to use these in a very careful way" to minimize risks to civilians, White House national security adviser Jake Sullivan said.

US President Joe Biden described the decision on cluster bombs as difficult but said Ukraine needed them .

"They're trying to get through those trenches, and stop those tanks from rolling," Biden said in an interview with CNN. "It was not an easy decision."

Grigory Karasin, head of the international committee in Federation Council, Russia's upper house of parliament, raised "serious concerns" about decisions by Washington and the NATO leadership, RIA news agency reported. It quoted Karasin as saying that Russia "of course, will respond to this."

Ukraine says it has taken back some villages in southern Ukraine since the counteroffensive began in early June, but that it lacks the firepower and air cover to make faster progress .

Reuters could not independently verify the battlefield situation.

"It's too early to judge how the counteroffensive is going one way or the other because we're at the beginning of the middle," Colin Kahl, the US under secretary of defense for policy, told reporters.

ZELENSKIY TOURS NATO COUNTRIES

Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskiy visited the Czech Republic, Slovakia and Turkey a day after talks in Bulgaria to drum up support for NATO membership before the alliance's July 11-12 summit.

In Prague, he won a pledge of support for Ukraine to join NATO "as soon as the war is over", and in Sofia secured backing for membership "as soon as conditions allow."

North Atlantic Treaty Organization Secretary-General Jens Stoltenberg reaffirmed his view that Ukraine would become a member.

"Our summit will send a clear message: NATO stands united, and Russia's aggression will not pay," Stoltenberg said at a news conference in Brussels.

It remained unclear, however, what Ukraine will be offered next week at the summit in Vilnius, the Lithuanian capital. The alliance is divided over how fast Ukraine should move towards membership, and some countries are wary of any step that might take NATO closer to war with Russia.

At the United Nations, aid chief Martin Griffiths warned Russia that it should not "chuck away" an agreement it made a year ago on the safe wartime passage of agricultural exports, known as the Black Sea Grain Initiative.

If Russia does not agree to extend the deal that allows export of grain and fertilizer from Ukrainian ports, it is unlikely Western states will continue cooperating with UN officials helping Moscow with its exports, Griffiths told reporters.

Russia has threatened to quit the deal, which expires on July 17, because several demands to export its own grain and fertilizer have not been met. The last three ships traveling under the deal are loading cargoes at the Ukrainian port of Odesa and are likely to depart on Monday.

"The world has seen the value of the Black Sea Initiative ... this isn't something you chuck away," Griffiths said.

The United Nations and Turkey brokered the deal with Russia and Ukraine in July 2022 to help tackle a global food crisis worsened by Moscow's invasion of its neighbor and blockade of Ukrainian Black Sea ports.

UN Secretary-General Antonio Guterres described the deals as playing an "indispensable role" in global food security.

Dutch Prime Minister Mark Rutte will hand in the resignation of his cabinet after failing to agree on measures to curb immigration, Dutch news agency ANP reported on Friday.

Rutte's office said he would hold an emergency cabinet meeting, but did not confirm the collapse of his fourth coalition government.

A push by Rutte's conservative VVD party to limit the flow of asylum seekers to the Netherlands split his four-party government coalition, as two junior parties refused to support his proposals.

Tensions came to a head this week, when Rutte demanded support for a proposal to limit entrance for children of war refugees who are already in the Netherlands and to make families wait at least two years before they can be united.

This last proposal made the small Christian Union decide to leave the government coalition, triggering a crisis.

A spokesman for the Christian Union could not immediately be reached for comment.

The Netherlands already has a one of Europe's toughest immigration policies but under the pressure of right-wing parties, Rutte had for months been trying to seek ways to further reduce the inflow of asylum seekers.

Asylum applications in the Netherlands jumped by a third last year to over 46,000, and the government has projected they could increase to more than 70,000 this year - topping the previous high of 2015.

This will again put a strain on the country's asylum facilities, where for months last year hundreds of refugees at a time were forced to sleep in the rough with little or no access to drinking water, sanitary facilities or health care.

Rutte last year said he felt "ashamed" of the problems, after humanitarian group Medecins sans Frontieres sent in a team to the Netherlands for the first time ever, to assist with migrants' medical needs at the centre for processing asylum requests.

He promised to improve conditions at the facilities, mainly by reducing the number of refugees that reach the Netherlands. But he failed to win the backing of coalition partners who felt his policies went too far.

The Postal Service on Sunday is raising overall first-class mail prices by 5.4% after the Postal Regulatory Commission gave approval.

First-class mail, used by most people to send letters and pay bills, is the highest revenue-generating mail class, accounting for $24.2 billion, or 31%, of the $78.8 billion in total USPS revenue in 2022.

In April, USPS cut projected losses through 2031 by more than half after winning financial relief from Congress, instituting regular price hikes and adopting reforms.

USPS is raising stamp prices twice yearly and expects its "new pricing policy to generate $44 billion in additional revenue" by 2031.

President Joe Biden signed legislation in April 2022 providing USPS with $48 billion in financial relief over a decade and required its future retirees to enroll in a government health insurance plan.

USPS has asked the Biden administration for accounting changes for retirement contributions that would eliminate amortization payments and save USPS $2 to $3 billion per year and up to $34.6 billion over 10 years.

Six people were injured after a fire broke out on Friday morning at an offshore platform run by Mexican state oil company Pemex in the Gulf of Mexico, the company said in a statement.

A company source, speaking to Reuters on condition of anonymity, said oil production remained unaffected.

Pemex said the fire started at the Nohoch-A joining platform and spread to a compression platform of the Cantarell complex in the Bay of Campeche.

Cantarell produces from one of Mexico's largest oil fields which for decades was one of Pemex's crown jewels. But production at Cantarell has now declined to 170,000 barrels per day (bpd), according to Pemex data.

Earlier on Friday, President Andres Manuel Lopez Obrador had said in a regular press conference that there were three or four people missing after the fire, but his spokesman Jesus Ramirez later told Reuters that was no longer the case.

In its statement, Pemex said that 321 of 328 people working on the platform had been evacuated.

"Part of the team is battling the fire," Ramirez said, explaining why some had not been evacuated.

The Pemex source said the company was still making checks to confirm exactly who had been on board at the time of the fire.

As Thames Water's financial troubles raise questions about such investments, Britain will next week try to persuade pension schemes to plough billions of pounds into infrastructure and start-ups in its next leg of post-Brexit reforms.

British Finance Minister Jeremy Hunt will on Monday set out the government's latest thinking on getting cash locked up in pension pots to work in the economy.

Britain is trying to re-establish its position in the world of global finance as it feels the impact of leaving the European Union's single market on one of its most important sectors.

Hunt is expected to announce a list of insurers and asset managers signed up in principle to invest more in alternative assets, a senior industry source said, during his annual speech to grandees of finance at the City of London's Mansion House.

The Conservative government's long-trailed policy focuses on persuading pension schemes to invest a portion of their money in infrastructure, start-ups and 'green' technology.

But the problems at Thames Water, which is battling for survival under 14 billion pounds ($18 billion) of debt, would leave some pension schemes that had made large investments in it embarrassed, said independent pensions consultant John Ralfe.

"It's not good news for a government that is banging the drum for companies investing in infrastructure," Ralfe said.

The finance ministry had no immediate comment on Hunt's speech, but the pensions industry has already said it opposes mandatory investment quotas.

A second senior industry source said they feared some reforms under discussion could introduce unnecessary risk to older, so-called defined benefit pension schemes, though there was some support for voluntary targets on defined contribution schemes where payouts for members were less certain.

These targets could include investing 5% of a pension pot in infrastructure and 5% in venture capital, but could mean higher fees due to their complexity. A public consultation on firmer proposals is expected in the autumn.

"They look like they are flailing around for a policy that might win them votes. But something as big as this will require primary legislation, and frankly, I don't think they will be able to fit this all in before an election," the source said.

Britain is expected to go to the polls next year, meaning time is running out to put forward new legislation.

Another executive at a global asset manager, who also declined to be named, said the most effective policy would be to combine pension pots in Britain's fragmented savings industry and emulate Australia's 'superannuation' pensions system, which could take time as previous attempts made slow progress.

"Nobody forced the Australians to invest in alternatives," this source said, adding that bigger pensions pots would likely be more inclined to allocate a proportion of their funds to riskier asset classes.

BREXIT IMPACT

Britain's financial services were largely cut off from the EU due to Brexit, with Amsterdam overtaking London as the region's biggest share trading centre.

UK chip designer ARM's decision to list in New York and not London has also piled pressure on Britain to bolster the City's attraction as a global financial centre.

An initial batch of reforms are already underway, and Hunt's speech will signal a new leg that also includes the outcome of a report which is expected to recommend ways to ease so-called 'unbundling' rules inherited from the EU.

These dictate how banks charge customers for research on companies to attract more listings. The EU is already easing its own version.

An update is also expected from a report on digitalising how stock and bond transactions are processed, which is expected to call for improvements in how companies communicate with their investors, and push for a fully paperless transaction trail, an industry source said.

Hunt could indicate if Britain intends to mirror Wall Street's move to halve the time for completing a stock trade to a day to increase efficiency and ease burdens on banks, the source added.
